articleinfo.title: Frequently Asked Questions about RELAX NG

question.para: How is "RELAX NG" pronounced?

answer.para: It's pronounced "relaxing".

question.para: Why does RELAX NG use an XML syntax?

answer.para: Seriously, is there any other choice?
If you don't want to write RELAX NG in XML syntax, there is a tool by James Clark that allows you to write RELAX NG schema in non-XML syntax and that tool will convert it to XML syntax for you.

question.para: Why is RELAX NG so verbose?

answer.para: If you find it too verbose for hand writing, there are tools that let you write one in more concise syntax. Check out the tools section.

question.para: What about entity declarations? Why doesn't RELAX NG allow me to declare entities? What do I do if I need to declare an entity?
What about notation declarations? Why doesn't RELAX NG allow me to declare notations? What do I do if I need to declare a notation?
Why doesn't RELAX NG do type assignment? How can I use RELAX NG if I want to do schema-based type assignment?

answer.para: Actually you can do the type assignment if you use a tool that supports it. For example, Sun Multi-Schema XML Validator supports the type assignment.

Since RELAX NG allows ambiguous grammars, type-assignment is not always possible. And in some other cases, type-assignment is possible but needs multiple passes. That's one of the reasons why we don't have type-assignment in our core spec.

question.para: How can I do data-binding with RELAX NG?

answer.para: There are not many, but there certainly exists tools for data-binding. For one, you can use Relaxer. Check out the tools section for more.

Why doesn't RELAX NG provide a documentation element?

RELAX NG allows you to write any elements and attributes to anywhere as long as it belongs to the namespace other than the RELAX NG namespace. So the above is completely legal.
Or another way to do this is to use elements of XHTML, DocBook, TEI or whatsoever. In this way, you can format your documents quite nicely.
answer.programlisting: <element xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> <anyName/> <xhtml:div> <xhtml:h1>Overview of this element</xhtml:h1> <xhtml:p>This element is used to do some craptacular thing</xhtml:p> </xhtml:div> ... </element>
answer.para: If you are looking for a plain simple text-only documentation, then you may want to use the documentation tag specified in the "RELAX NG DTD compatibility specification". No, you don't need to read the spec. Just use the documentation element in the http://relaxng.org/ns/annotation/0.9 namespace. For example,
answer.programlisting: <element xmlns:a="http://relaxng.org/ns/annotation/0.9"> <anyName/> <a:documentation> This element is used to save the world from starvation. </a:documentation> ... </element>
answer.para: As I wrote earlier, you can write this element anywhere in the schema.

question.para: I read that RELAX NG is based on "regular tree languages"? What's that all about? Does it have any practical benefits?

answer.para: As long as you are using RELAX NG, you don't need to know anything about those geeky stuff. But yes, it does have several practical benefits.

listitem.para: The validation algorithm becomes simple because this theory is well-studied. This contributes to make validators smaller and faster.
It enables static analysis of schemas: is anything allowed by one schema also allowed by another schema?

question.para: Why does RELAX NG base itself on grammars? Isn't a constraint-based approach like Schematron more powerful?

answer.para: One answer to this question is, the grammar-based approach is well-studied by scientists and (therefore) the validation is relatively fast.
Also, there will be tools available which let you combine RELAX NG and Schematron. Check out the tools section.

I read that, unlike DTDs and XML Schema, RELAX NG does not prohibit ambiguous content models? Does this have any practical benefit?
What's the use of the interleave element in RELAX NG?

answer.para: One of the frequent use would be to implement an unordered content model ( XML Schema's <all> particle.)
Another nice technique is to implement a "set" of tokens.

question.para: What's the use of the parentRef element in RELAX NG? What's the use of nested grammars?
What's the use of the combine attribute in RELAX NG?

answer.para: Practically, combine="choice" and combine="interleave" serve two completely different purposes.

listitem.para: One of the use case of combine="choice" is to create an implicit "class" of elements.
listitem.programlisting:
<define name="inline.class" combine="choice"> <element name="b"> ... </element> </define>
<define name="inline.class" combine="choice"> <element name="i"> ... </element> </define>
listitem.para: In this way, each element can collaboratively form a class of elements, without any central control. This is useful when writing a modularized schema.
Another common use of combine="choice" is to extend an already defined "class" of elements.
listitem.programlisting:
<define name="list.class"> <choice> <ref name="dl"/> <ref name="ul"/> <ref name="ol"/> </choice> </define>
<define name="list.class" combine="choice"> <ref name="xl"/> </define>
